content: An error was made in transferring the profile. With more information, more assistance can be suggested. If you have a backup of the profile, I can assist in doing an install. The error is in the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder. for a 'fresh install', delete the appdata\local\thunderbird folder and the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder and then reinstall from thunderbird.net. start thunderbird once and then exit. At this point, I can assist in the transfer. Is your baclup of just the profile, or of the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder?

content:
"Caldav" is a protocol for synchronizing calendars, and one.com is a web site host, so "caldav.one.com" suggests that Thunderbird is trying to connect to a calendar on one.com.

Who is your email host? Do you use Thunderbird's Calendar feature, and where is it hosted? You can check that by going to calendar tab, right-click on the calendar list in the left pane, choosing Properties, and examining the Location.

If this is something that just recently started up, I wonder if your hosting service is either having problems or is in the process of offloading some of their services, like calendaring to another provider.
creator: rednoise

content:
Just to be clear: the webmail account and what is on your PC is the same account. It will help ensuring we're using the same words if you would post what is on your 'server setting' pane. It will say either 'IMAP mail server' or 'POP mail server'. To see it, click 'account settings' and then click the 'server settings' for the account. Everything I write here assumes it says IMAP.

If you want all messages on PC and not on server, the only choice is POP. When you click to get messages, the messages will download to PC and be removed from server. If you later wish to read messages on your phone, they will not be there. If you have the phone set for IMAP, you can read messages FIRST on the phone, but if you read messages on PC first, then they will have been removed. If you are using IMAP and have a folder structure, that structure will not be accessible with a POP account, but you can create a new structure on PC for future messages.

You mentioned two accounts. My guess is that the provider stopped using POP and now uses IMAP. Is one account the old POP account and you also have an IMAP account for same email address? Seeing specifics would help. If the provider switched from POP to IMAP, is setting up POP even allowed. Maybe if you posted screenshots of the server settings pane for both accounts, that may help.
creator: davidsk

creator: sjguillemin17

content:
You can tell if IMAP or POP3 by looking at (on Windows) <Tools | Account Settings | (email account) | Server Settings>. There you will see the Server Type.

In this case, it might be most expeditious to just go to the Gmail web interface and delete the messages there. Keep in mind that when Gmail "deletes" a message, it goes into the Trash folder and will still be included when you look at Thunderbird's "All Mail" folder until Trash is emptied. This is a quirk of Gmail and is why it's recommended to unsubscribe in Thunderbird from All Mail.

After you delete the messages on Gmail web, you should Compact all the folders on Thunderbird.

content:
Note - Manual junk controls did not work on virtual folders prior to version 140, but that should have been fixed in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1967664 and I see you are using version 140.

And to clarify a point, automatic spam processing only occurs on REAL folders. So your description is slightly confusing.

Perhaps you are seeing a case where the unified folder view is not being updated with changes from the underlying real folder?
